__data__.text: President Idi Amin ruled Uganda.
During President Idi Amin's rule, many Ugandan people were killed.
Minority groups were among those killed in Uganda during President Idi Amin's rule.
Many others were tortured in Uganda during President Idi Amin's rule.
In South Africa, incidents of police brutality increased by 312% from 2011 to 2012 compared to 2001 to 2002.
In South Africa, from 2011 to 2012, only 1 in 100 cases of police brutality led to a conviction.
In South Africa, from 2011 to 2012, there were 720 deaths in police custody due to police action.
In 2015, in South Africa, police officers were accused of crimes such as rape, torture, and murder.
In 2015, in South Africa, the cost of civil liabilities claims was great as a result of police officers being accused of crimes.
In 2015, in South Africa, there was concern that the costs of civil liabilities claims would strain the South African Police Service national budget.
Police commissioner Riah Phiyega blamed the large number of claims in South Africa in 2015 on a highly litigious climate.
Police brutality has spread throughout Soweto, South Africa.
Nathaniel Julius was a 16 year old boy with Down Syndrome.
Nathaniel Julius was killed in Soweto by police officers from the El Dorado police station.
Nathaniel Julius was killed because he didn't respond to a police officer calling him.
Nathaniel Julius didn't have any weapons on him when he was killed.
Nathaniel Julius was just walking from the store after buying biscuits when he was killed.
Two police officers were arrested over Julius' death in Soweto on murder charges.
The arrests of the two police officers in Soweto were after mass protests against the killing of Nathan
Chinese protesters have been able to organize powerful group demonstrations using social media and informal mass communication platforms like Twitter and its Chinese counterpart Weibo.
Xintang, in Canton Province (Guangzhou), is an influential textile hub that attracts thousands of workers from all over the country.
A complaint of mistreatment against a pregnant migrant worker was the cause of protests in Xintang.
Protests in Xintang on 20 February urged participants to take a quiet walk in specific places instead of shouting anti-government slogans.
The police responded brutally to the protests in Xintang.
After the protests in Xintang, authorities installed corrugated metal fences outside the restaurant and the home of dissident Liu Xiaobo.
Hundreds of uniformed and plainclothes security officers and volunteers with red armbands were positioned in Wangfujing, interrupting the orderly operation of the shops.
During the 2014 Hong Kong protests, there were instances of police brutality, including seven police officers kicking and beating a prominent political activist who was already handcuffed.
There were also more than hundreds of incidents of police beating passers-by with batons during the 2014 Hong Kong protests.
Demonstrators were dragged behind police lines, circled by police officers to block onlookers' views, and re-emerged with visible injuries.
Retired police officer Frankly Chu King-wai was sentenced to three months in prison for causing serious bodily harm during the 2014 Hong Kong protests.
Complaints of police brutality increased substantially during the 2019-2020 Hong Kong protests, breaking previous records.
The police's mauling and intentional head-shooting of protesters by rubber bullets and rapid tear-gassing of a surrounded crowd caused numerous critical injuries.
Many Hong Kong citizens accuse the police of attempting to murder protesters to deter the people from exercising their freedom of expression.
Amnesty International released a report on 21 June 2019 denouncing the role of the Hong Kong
The police's actions in a certain situation were widely condemned.
Masoumeh Ebtekar, Iran's vice-president for women's affairs, was among those who condemned the police's actions.
Iran's interior ministry ordered an inquiry into the police's actions.
On September 13, 2022, Mahsa Amini, a Kurdish woman, was detained by authorities.
Mahsa Amini was announced dead on September 16, 2022.
The cause of Mahsa Amini's death was alleged to be cardiac arrest.
It is likely that Mahsa Amini's death was due to injuries acquired from the brutality she encountered.
Mahsa Amini's death sparked massive protests.
Women were seen burning the mandatory headscarf during the protests.
The head of Tehran's morality police was later suspended.
Saddam Hussein, the former leader of Iraq, used the police to arrest anyone who opposed him.
During India's independence struggle, protestors and activists were subject to Lathi charges and shootings.

The Jallianwala Bagh massacre is an incident in India where a crowd gathered to protest the Rowlatt act were indiscriminately fired at, on the orders of a British Officer, General Dyer with 200 casualties.
During the emergency of 1975-1977 in India, several cases of Police Brutality were recorded.
On 31 March 1976, the Rajan case was one of the incidents of Police Brutality recorded in India.
On 23 January 2017, a pro-jallikattu silent protest in Tamil Nadu turned violent.
The National Human Rights Commission reported that the police used violent methods without prior warning, including beatings and damaging private property, to disperse protesters in Chennai.
There were widespread social media reports of police setting vehicles on fire during the protest in Chennai.
On 15 December
Issa was arrested.
A court found Issa not guilty and released him.
Amnesty International reported that a worker from the United Arab Emirates (UAE) was subjected to torture during his time in jail.
The torture of the UAE worker included beatings and sleep deprivation.
Prisoners in the UAE are treated poorly and are tortured.
Authorities in Saudi Arabia have been filmed lashing civilians for different reasons.
Jamal Khashoggi was a Saudi-American activist.
In October 2018, Jamal Khashoggi went into the Saudi Embassy in Turkey.
On the same day, a group of Saudi authorities entered Turkey and intercepted Jamal Khashoggi at the Embassy.
The Saudi authorities killed Jamal Khashoggi soon after intercepting him.
The Saudi authorities disposed of Jamal Khashoggi's body and then returned to Saudi Arabia.
In Bahrain, police and military personnel manhandled and shot dead many Arab Spring protesters.
Pakistan's law enforcement is divided into multiple tiers, including forces under provincial and federal government control.
The law in Pakistan strictly prohibits any physical abuse of suspected or convicted criminals.
There have been reported instances of suspected police brutality in Pakistan due to deficiencies during the training process.
Reported cases of police brutality in Pakistan are often investigated by police authorities as well as civil courts, leading to mixed outcomes.
In October 2019, the People National Alliance organized a rally to free Kashmir from Pakistani rule.
The police tried to stop the rally in Pakistan, resulting in 100 people being injured.
In 1976, Thai police, military personnel, and others shot at protesters at Thammasat University in Thailand.
Many protesters were killed in the shooting, and many survivors were abused.
Turkey has a history of police brutality, including the use of torture between 1977 and 2002.
Turkish police have used excessive force, such
In 1997, Nicola Jevremović was fined for a misdemeanor and found guilty of "resisting arrest".
Violetta Jevremović was found guilty of "suspicion of resisting arrest" in 1997.
In November 1998, Dr. C, a black Austrian citizen, was stopped by police after reversing his car into a one-way street.
Police asked Dr. C, "Why are you driving the wrong way, nigger?".
Dr. C was beaten unconscious and handcuffed by police in November 1998.
Police continued beating Dr. C after he regained consciousness.
Dr. C spent 11 days recovering in the hospital after his arrest in November 1998.
In May 1999, Marcus Omofuma, a Nigerian asylum-seeker, was being deported from Vienna.
Officers taped Omofuma to his chair "like a mummy" and stuck tape over his mouth during his deportation.
Omofuma suffocated whilst in police custody in May 1999.
On New Year's Eve, a 47-year-old woman was beaten and taken into custody after refusing to take a breathalyzer test while walking home.
The woman suffered a fractured coccyx, and severe bruising to her head and knees.
The woman filed a complaint and received no response.
The case was re-examined by the prosecutor only after the woman found CCTV footage.
In July 2015, a 27-year-old man was handcuffed and violently thrown to the ground while in police custody.
Police said that the man had been injured while "pressing his head against the wall".
Video evidence showed the man being passive and compliant before the altercation.
From 2014 to 2015, 250 accusations of police misconduct were made against officers in Vienna with none being charged.
In a similar time period, 1,3
In May 2021, Belarusian authorities stopped Ryanair Flight 4978 in Belarusian airspace.
Roman Protasevich, a Belarusian journalist and activist, was taken off the plane and detained by Belarusian authorities.
In 2001, Belgium changed to a two-tier police system, consisting of federal and local police forces.
The two services in Belgium remain independent but have integrated common training programs and recruitment.
The change in Belgium's police system was prompted by a national parliamentary report into a series of pedophile murders, which proved police negligence and severely diminished public confidence.
Currently, approximately 33,000 local police and 900 civilians work across 196 regional police forces in Belgium.
The United Nations (UN) Basic Principles on the Use of Force and Firearms by Law Enforcement Officials (1990) are replicated in Belgian law through The Criminal Code and the Police Functions Act.
The UN Human Rights Committee reported complaints of ill-treatment against property and people by Belgian police escalated between 2005 and 2011.
Most commonly, Belgian police were found to have assaulted persons who no longer posed danger.
Belgian judicial authorities failed to notify national police watchdog, Committee P, of criminal convictions against police.
This failure to notify is a direct breach of Belgian judicial procedure and a failure to comply with Article 40 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

In January 2010, Jonathan Jacob died from internal bleeding following an incident where he was restrained and beaten by eight officers from Antwerp police's Special Intervention Unit after being injected with a sedative.
The incident sparked public outrage, but police claimed they did not make any mistakes and "acted carefully, respecting the necessary precautions".

In 2013, the Grand Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) convicted Belgium of human rights violations in an appeal on the treatment of two brothers in custody who had been slapped by an officer
A person died in police custody in Croatia. The circumstances of his death are unknown.
The Constitution of Croatia prohibits torture, mistreatment, and cruel and degrading punishment under Article 17.
The Constitution of Croatia accords arrested and convicted persons humane treatment under Article 25 of the OHCHR.
Croatia has a centralised police force under the command of the Ministry of the Interior with approximately 20,000 police officers.
From 1991 to 1995, the Croatian police were a militarised force charged with the role of defending the country while seceding from Yugoslavia.
Military training taught police officers to use firearms before exhausting other procedures.
The philosophy and behaviour of police officers in using excessive force has been affected by the early 1990s militarisation of the police force.
Developments have been made to achieve democratic policing in Croatia.

Citizen complaints of violent police behaviour suggest that the militarization of the police force continues to influence the level of force accepted as legitimate and reasonable by Croatian police officers.

The European Court of Human Rights has found that Croatian police authorities have failed to fulfill their obligations under Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.
This failure to fulfill obligations includes not carrying out effective investigations to protect citizens and tourists from violent attacks.
In 2009, the European Court of Human Rights condemned Croatian police authorities for ignoring requests to start an investigation into perpetrators who violently attacked a Croatian citizen.
The Croatian police have a history of discriminatory abuse and failing to recognise violence against the Romani minority living in Croatia.
Reports of police abuse against minority groups including Romani have been continually reported.
Police authorities are reluctant to take violence against Romani people seriously.
Police investigations into black market selling in Croatia have been excessively violent towards Romani vendors.
Reports of physical violence and abusive racism being directed at Romani vendors have been made.
In 2002, the Rom
In 2002, Jens Arne Orskov Mathiason died while in police custody on the way to prison.
The death of Jens Arne Orskov Mathiason raised concerns over the behavior of the officers involved.
The thoroughness of the subsequent investigation was questioned.
The Director of Public Prosecutions was criticized for their willingness to hold the officers accountable for their alleged failings.

Amnesty International called for the establishment of new policies to investigate human rights violations and enforce compliance under the European Convention on Human Rights after the death of Jens Arne Orskov Mathiason.
In January 2016, a man died in police custody after being arrested by seven Copenhagen Police officers.
In August 2009, police in Copenhagen were heavily criticized for their response to an attempt to remove Iraqi refugees who were living in a city church.
Video allegedly showed the police using violence against the refugees and their supporters in August 2009.
Between 12,000 and 20,000 people protested against the actions of the police in August 2009.

In 2012, the Danish Court of Appeal concluded that the Danish Police had violated Article 3 of the European Convention of Human Rights for the 2009 mass arrest made during protests at the 2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen.
The Danish Police had also violated Articles 5, 10, and 11 of the European Convention of Human Rights for the 2009 mass arrest.
Police recruits in Denmark undergo approximately three years of training.
The National Police College in Denmark provides training for police recruits.

During the three-year training period in Denmark, recruits learn about police theory, the Road Traffic Act, criminal law, physical training, other legislation, first aid, radio communication, securing evidence, identifying drugs, preventing crime, management, human rights, and cultural sociology.
After the three-year training period, recruits are promoted to the position of a police constable in Denmark.
US
The Bronze Soldier of Tallinn is a statue that was relocated in April 2007.
The relocation of the Bronze Soldier of Tallinn was done by the government to rebury the associated remains near the Tallinn Military Cemetery.
The Russophone population in the country reacted negatively to the relocation of the Bronze Soldier of Tallinn.
For Estonians, the Bronze Soldier served as a symbol of Soviet occupation and repression.
For Russian citizens, the Bronze Soldier represented Soviet Russia's victory over Germany in World War II and their claim to equal rights in Estonia.
In April 2007, riots broke out over the relocation of the Bronze Soldier of Tallinn.
One Russian rioter was killed and other protesters were arrested during the Bronze Night.
Andrei Zarenkov, then-chairman of the Constitution Party, made claims of police brutality during the Bronze Night.
The police department denied all claims made against them regarding police brutality during the Bronze Night.
The Office of Prosecutor General of Estonia received more than fifty complaints on the police brutality that occurred during Bronze Night.
The United Nations Committee against torture expressed concerns over the use of excessive force and brutality by law enforcement personnel in regards to Bronze Night.
The Council of Europe published a report stating that those detained during Bronze Night were not granted all the fundamental safeguards.
The nineteenth century France had a policing structure that has been linked to the outcomes of France's reorganisation during the French Revolution.
There have been multiple instances of violent enforcement in France due to issues around racial and geographic differences.

Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International reported human rights violations by France including physical and psychological abuse as a result of excessive force towards Muslims when undertaking house raids.
France's police ombudsman is currently dealing with 48 judicial inquiries into police brutality against its citizens.
In a three-month period, 1,000 individuals were arrested in France due to police brutality.
There have been several high-profile cases
The yellow vests protests in France started due to an increased fuel tax made by President Emmanuel Macron.
Participation in the weekly protests in France decreased due to violence, including the loss of eyes and hands, and the development of neurological disorders caused by police blast balls.
The yellow vests protests in France stopped due to the COVID-19 pandemic but resumed after health restrictions were lifted.
In June 2023, widespread protests began in France after the killing of Nahel Merzouk.
Historically, police brutality was commonplace in Finland during the 1920s and 1930s following the Finnish Civil War.
In 2006, there were 7,700 police officers in Finland.
In 2006, the Finnish police force was seen to be more law-abiding than firemen.
In 2006, a few dozen cases each year involved Finnish police officers being convicted of crimes committed while on duty.
In 2006, approximately 50% of the cases involving Finnish police officers were traffic-related crimes.
In 2006, approximately 20% of the cases involving Finnish police officers were for the use of excessive force.
In 2006, a 51-year-old Finnish police constable raped a 16-year-old girl twice after getting her drunk.
In 2007, Rasoul Pourak, an Iranian-born immigrant, was beaten in a cell at Pasila Police Station, Helsinki, resulting in bruises, an open wound, a fractured skull, and facial bone damage.
In 2010, two Finnish police officers broke a man's femur during an arrest.
In 2013, two Finnish policemen were sentenced to 35 day-fines for assault and breach of duty in connection with stomping on a Romani man's head onto the asphalt three times.
Germany is sensitive towards its history in implementing policing practices.
International bodies have identified a clear pattern of police ill-t
Ageeb was restrained by tape and rope before the departure of a flight.
During take-off of the flight, police officers allegedly forced Ageeb's head and upper body between his knees.
On 8 December 2000, Josef Hoss was accused by his neighbor, who was a police officer, of harboring firearms.
Hoss was ambushed, beaten, and handcuffed near his home.
Hoss woke up in a police station with a cloth bag over his head and sustained multiple injuries.
The injuries prevented Hoss from working or being able to financially support his family.
No firearms were found during the investigation.
In May 2002, Stephan Neisius was repeatedly kicked and hit by a group of police officers while he was handcuffed on the floor of a police station.
Neisius spent 13 days in hospital on life support before dying.
The Cologne District Court convicted all six police officers of bodily harm resulting in death.
None of the accused police officers served prison sentences.
Teresa Z. called the police after a fight with her boyfriend in 2012.
Teresa Z. was quickly arrested.
Police officer Frank W. punched Teresa Z. while she was in detention.
Teresa Z. received a broken nose and eye socket as a result of the punch.
Frank W. spent ten months in jail.
Frank W. was forced to pay a fine of 3,000 euros.
In Germany, law enforcement is vested solely with the states of Germany.
Each state's police force (or "Land" police) follows a different system of law.
There is an absence of a federal comprehensive register in Germany.
The register would compile and publish regular, uniform, and comprehensive figures on complaints about police ill-treatment.
Germany is bound to obligate its many international treaties and conventions.
Amnesty International highlighted that the authorities failed to protect a range of human rights as guaranteed by international human rights law and standards in 2002.
In 1980, Stamatina Kanelopoulou, who was 20 years old, died during a demonstration commemorating the Athens Polytechnic uprising. Her death was caused by beatings from the Greek police.
In 1980, Iakovos Koumis, who was 24 years old, died during a demonstration commemorating the Athens Polytechnic uprising. His death was caused by beatings from the Greek police.
Protests still occur in Greece to commemorate the 1973 uprising. These protests often experience police brutality around the time of the event.
In 1985, Michalis Kaltezas, who was 15 years old, was murdered by the police during a demonstration commemorating the Polytechnic uprising.
Over the last few years, police brutality in Greece has been severe. This increase is linked to the financial crisis and the implementation of austerity measures.

Greek citizens have opposed austerity measures with strikes and demonstrations. In response, police brutality has increased, with reports of tear gas use, severe injuries inflicted by police, and unjustified detention of protesters.

In 2013, four young men believed to be bank robbery suspects were allegedly tortured by Greek police following their arrest. The police claimed they used Photoshop to ensure the suspects were recognizable in their press release.

In October 2012, 15 anti-fascist protesters were arrested in Athens after clashing with supporters of the fascist party "Golden Dawn". They claimed they were tortured while being held at the Attica General Police Directorate.
Police brutality in Greece today primarily manifests as unjustified and extreme physical violence towards protesters and journalists.
Amnesty International has expressed concern about the continued targeting of journalists, as it infringes on the right to freedom of expression.

In November 2014, there were multiple instances of police using excessive brutal force, misusing less-lethal weapons against protesters, attacking journalists, and subjecting bystanders to ill-treatment.
In
The student experienced violence and was afraid of police because he had previously seen them beating a man they had arrested.
A group of police officers allegedly assaulted the student with batons, replaced by another group of police officers, causing him injuries.
The student was unarmed and did not pose a threat.
In May 2011, student Yannis Kafkas suffered a severe head injury after a police officer hit him with a fire extinguisher.
Kafkas spent 20 days in intensive care due to the injury.
In June 2011, journalist Manolis Kipraios lost his hearing permanently after a stun grenade was fired at him by a riot police member.
In February 2012, photojournalist Marios Lolos required surgery after being beaten in the head by police at a protest.
The day before this attack, journalist Rena Maniou was allegedly severely beaten by security forces.
Dimitris Trimis, head of The Greek Journalist Association (ESEA), broke his arm after being violently pushed and kicked by police.
There have been instances where protesters were used as human shields by police.
None of the police brutality cases resulted in any prosecution of police force members.
The death of 15-year-old Alexis Grigoropoulos, shot dead by a police officer in December 2008, sparked nationwide riots against police brutality.
The police force in Hungary consists of the National Bureau of Investigation, the Operational Police, and Terrorelhárítási Központ.
In 2008, Hungary's two law enforcement bodies merged, and Border Guards became police officers.
The Rendőrség force in Hungary has 44,923 employees.
Brutality and corruption exist within the Rendőrség police force in Hungary.
The Roma minority in Hungary has faced discrimination, including police mistreatment and brutality.
In 2006, police used disproportionate measures during protests against Prime Minister Fer
The requirements to become a police officer in Hungary include graduating from high school, passing a matriculation exam, and completing two years in the police academy.
The two-year police academy program in Hungary is shorter than Denmark's (3-year program), but longer than Australia's (33-week program) and the United States' (18 weeks).
The Hungarian police academy focuses on academic theory and not much on practice.
Police brutality incidents in Hungary might decrease if practical work was given more attention in the Hungarian police academy.
Northern Ireland has experienced long-standing issues with police brutality due to unsavoury police procedures during the Troubles.
The Troubles in Northern Ireland took place from 1968 to 2007 and involved a civil war between unionists/loyalists (mostly Protestants) and Irish nationalists/republicans (mostly Catholics).

The European Court of Human Rights reported in 1978 that five interrogation techniques used by the police in Northern Ireland, including wall standing, deprivation of food, drink or sleep, subjection to noise, and forcing detainees to remain in the same position for hours, were instances of cruel and degrading treatment.
Domestic courts in Northern Ireland did not recognize police brutality until 2010, when 113 people, some of them minors, came forward with their complaints.

Present-day Northern Ireland still faces policing issues, including harassment by police against children aged 14-18 in low socio-economic areas, leading to a deep level of mistrust between the youth and the police.

Catholics in Northern Ireland report being treated differently by police due to the police force being largely Protestant, with 48% of Catholics surveyed in Northern Ireland reporting harassment by the police.
Instances of harassment in Northern Ireland include police officials spitting on individuals or enforcing laws in a discriminatory fashion.

The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) has moved away from police brutality, focusing on accountability for the past and significantly decreasing the use of the baton amongst police members, though harassment remains an issue.
The Garda, which is a police force, engaged independent Human Rights experts to conduct a review.
The review of the Garda found numerous deficiencies.
The government responded to the review by implementing new procedures.
The new procedures include a new complaints procedure against the Garda, which is the Ombudsman Commission.
The new procedures also include disciplinary procedures.
The new procedures further include whistle-blowing protections.
In Italy, the use of excessive violence by police officers has been a major concern since the 2000s.
On July 11, 2001, during the anti-globalization demonstration outside the July 2001 G8 summit, Carlo Giuliani, who was 23 years old, was killed by police officers.
The police officers opened fire on a group of protesters, resulting in Giuliani's death.
Mario Placanica, who was a 25-year-old police officer, was considered to be responsible for Giuliani's death.
Placanica was not charged for Giuliani's death.
Placanica claimed that he was being used as a scapegoat to cover up for the responsible parties.
Placanica also claimed that other officers caused Giuliani's death by shooting at him from a nearby location.
Nobody was arrested for Giuliani's murder.
On July 11, 2003, Marcello Lonzi, who was 29 years old, died in his cell.
Lonzi was arrested in Livorno four months prior as he was suspected of carrying out an attempted theft.
Although Lonzi's death was considered to be caused by "a heart attack after a fall", signs of torture were found on his body.
Nobody was arrested for Lonzi's death.
On September 25, 2005, in Ferrara, Federico Aldrovandi, who was 18 years old, was stopped by four policemen.
The four officers began to beat and torture Aldrovandi, resulting in his
S.S. Lazio is a football club.
Five men support S.S. Lazio.
A car of Juventus supporters stopped the five Lazio supporters.
A fight erupted between the two groups.
Policeman Luigi Spaccarotella intervened in the fight.
Spaccarotella opened fire and killed Gabriele Sandri with a single gunshot wound to his neck.
Spaccarotella was sentenced to nine years and five months in prison.
Spaccarotella was freed in 2017 with semi-liberty.
Giuseppe Uva was stopped by two police officers in Varese.
The police officers demanded to see Uva's documents.
Uva refused to show his documents.
Uva angrily kicked at the door of a nearby house.
Other police officers arrived at the scene.
Uva and his friend Alberto Bigigoggero were arrested.
Uva died the next morning.
Signs of violence were found on Uva's body.
Bigigoggero confirmed that Uva had been tortured.
Attorney general Massimo Gaballo asked for ten years of imprisonment for each of the eight officers involved in Uva's death.
None of the officers were charged.
Uva's sister insisted that her brother was murdered.
Luigi Manconi promised to fight for the truth regarding Uva's death.
Stefano Cucchi was an Italian man who resided regularly at a home in Rome.
Cucchi was stopped by five policemen in Rome on 15 October 2009.
The policemen saw Cucchi selling transparent packaging to a man in exchange for money.
Cucchi was arrested and brought to a police station.
Officers found cocaine and hashish in Cucchi's pocket.
Cucchi had medicine for epilepsy in his pocket.
Cucchi was affected by epilepsy.
Several prostitutes were beaten and threatened by officers.
Seven officers were sentenced to prison for the abuse, receiving terms between three and twelve years.
On 1 July 2021, 52 prison guards were arrested and suspended.
The arrests were due to charges of aggravated torture, aggravated ill-treatment, and causing multiple injuries to prisoners.
The prisoners were beaten by guards at the Santa Maria Capua Vetere prison in Caserta.
The beating of prisoners occurred on 6 April 2020.
The prisoners were beaten after a riot erupted due to inmates demanding face masks and Covid-19 tests in reaction to a virus outbreak.
Inmates were allegedly made to strip, kneel, and be beaten by guards.
Guards wore helmets to conceal their identity.
Latvia is a country that became an independent republic in 1918.
Latvia attempted to develop an effective and accepted police force, moving away from the untrusted Russian Tsarist administration.
The National Militia was created in Latvia in response to underfunding and under-resourcing of the police.
The National Militia consisted of a group of volunteers to protect public order.
Policing during this period in Latvia was successful and was assimilated to what is today referred to as community policing.
From 1940 to 1991, Latvia was occupied by the Soviet Union.
During the Soviet occupation, all previous regulations and practices were overruled by the Communist regime.
The Soviet militsiya was brought into Latvia by the Communist regime.
Soviet ideals on policing considered criminals to be the enemy.
A high level of institutional secrecy existed in the Soviet militsiya.
There was no independent review of policing in the Soviet militsiya.
The approach of community policing was replaced with a militarised authority based on Marxist ideologies in the Soviet militsiya.
An imbalance existed between police actions and citizens' rights in the Soviet militsiya
The European Committee for the Prevention of Torture (CPT) has assessed the Latvian criminal justice system several times since 2004.
The CPT gives recommendations for improvements to appropriate authorities, such as a review board for ill-treatment.
In 2011, the CPT found that Latvian authorities did not enact any of their 2007 recommendations.
The 2011 CPT report outlined cases of police brutality within the Latvian prison system.
Allegations of police brutality in Latvia include punching, kicking, misuse of police batons, and excessively tight handcuffing.
These incidents of police brutality in Latvia mostly occur during apprehension or at the police station, including during questioning.
Despite the flaws within the Latvian Police system, the CPT has found that the number of allegations for poor treatment is decreasing over the years.
The Latvian Police force operates under the Professional Ethics and Conduct Code of the State Police Personnel.
The Latvian Police code states that a police officer shall only use force, special facilities, or weapons in cases stipulated by law.
The Luxembourg Police force, also known as the "Grand Ducal Police," has 1,603 officers.
The Grand Ducal Police is the primary law enforcement agency in Luxembourg and has been operating since 2000.
Luxembourg has a relatively small population of approximately 500,000 people.
The Grand Ducal Police are in charge of several duties that are often separated by jurisdictions, such as Border Control and Internal Military operations.
Police brutality is not perceived to be a serious threat to society in Luxembourg.
The European Union's 2014 Anti-Corruption report placed Luxembourg as having one of the lowest incidents of reported police brutality within the European Union.
Luxembourg has positive characteristics in its society, such as freedom of media, the encouragement of public participation in the legal system, and transparency mechanisms.
The public has a deep trust in the Grand Ducal police force.
There are approximately 1,900 members in the Force. Under the Police Act of 1961, Part V deals with the use of force.
Police officers may use such moderate and proportionate force as may be necessary according to Article 96 of the Police Act of 1961.
Using force for considerations extraneous to those permitted by law and the circumstances of the case is considered an offence against discipline according to Article 100 of the Police Act of 1961.
Malta recognizes the illegality of police brutality and can prosecute offending officials on these grounds.
Malta is expected to abide by the 2001 European Code of Ethics as a member of the European Union.
The police may use force only when strictly necessary and only to the extent required to obtain a legitimate objective according to the 2001 European Code of Ethics.
The Council of Europe follows the five principles developed by the European Court of Human Rights.
Police officers may use reasonable force when lawfully exercising powers according to definition 16 of the five principles developed by the European Court of Human Rights.
In 2008, Lawrence Gonzi, The Minister for Justice and Home Affairs, called upon Martin Scicluna to conduct an independent inquiry into a police brutality incident.
The inquiry investigated allegations of beatings carried out on detainees at Safi Detention Centre by members of the Detention Service on 24 March 2008.
Martin Scicluna made recommendations that appropriate action should be taken to reprimand the Detention Service officers involved in the operation.
Home Affairs Minister Carm Mifsud Bonnici said 95 percent of the members of the police force were doing their duties, but the remainder needed to be addressed.
The Internal Affairs Unit (IAU) was established to maintain and safeguard the integrity of the Malta Police Force.
The IAU is an internal system of investigation that is objective, fair, equitable, impartial and just.
Complaints or allegations on the use of force can be monitored and responded to by the IAU.
The US Department of State
The Netherlands is a signatory to the European Convention on Human Rights.
The European Convention on Human Rights outlines the limits and responsibilities of police powers.
The Netherlands has a public commitment to the restricted legal use of police powers.
The police force of the Netherlands is divided into 25 regional forces and one central force.
A Regional Police Board heads each regional force.
The Regional Police Board is made up of local mayors and the chief public prosecutor.
A chief officer is placed in charge of police operations in each regional force.
The Rijksrecherche is the national agency responsible for the investigation of serious breaches of police conduct resulting in death or injury in the Netherlands.
In 2007, the Rijksrecherche conducted 67 inquiries related to police officers in the Netherlands.
Twenty-one of the inquiries conducted by the Rijksrecherche in 2007 were related to shootings in the Netherlands.
Dutch society has a history of support for liberal values.
The Netherlands has subjected racial minorities to racial profiling.
The Netherlands has experienced increased levels of police violence towards racial minorities.
Suspicion and mistrust of some racial groups is evident in the Netherlands.
Police attitudes perpetuate this suspicion and mistrust of some racial groups in the Netherlands.
Amnesty International has commented on the correlation of suspicious criminal behavior with specific ethnic characteristics in the Netherlands.
The ethnic characteristic most notably correlated with suspicious criminal behavior in the Netherlands is that of persons of Moroccan heritage.
Current political discourse in the Netherlands supports the notion of inferiority of some cultures.
The growth in support for far-right political ideologies has been observed in recent decades in the Netherlands.
A notable case of racial profiling and the use of police force occurred in June 2015 with the death of Aruban man Mitch Henriquez in the Netherlands.
Mitch Henriquez died of asphyxiation while in police custody after being suspected of carrying a firearm and being arrested at a music festival in The Hague, Netherlands.
The first anniversary
Polish police have been arresting protesters and using gas against them on the streets.
The Polish government states that the use of force was necessary, even though there was no reported example of aggression on the side of protesters.
In recent years, there have been issues with sports fans in Poland.
In 1998, major riots occurred when a young basketball fan was killed by the police.
In 2004, a man was killed and a woman injured in a riot when Polish police accidentally shot live ammunition instead of rubber bullets into the crowd after an association football game.
In 2015, riots occurred in response to a pitch invasion during a football match.
Although rubber bullets were used, one man was hit in the neck and later died at the hospital.
A former police officer justified the use of weapons as a means to combat football hooliganism.
Protesters have characterized the detainment of sports fans protesting against the government as unfair and undemocratic.
The Polish police have a history of police brutality within the Roma community.
There are multiple cases of police beatings and other discriminatory acts against the Roma by the police.
The European Roma Rights Centre argues that investigations into police brutality cases are seldom carried out.
The police brutality against the Roma minority is systematic.
In 1998, the police took four Roma men to a field and beat them.
The men that were beaten were hospitalised for broken bones and other injuries.
They were charged with vulgar words and behavior in public.
Portugal is ranked the fourth most heavily policed country in the world.
The police force is divided into five main organizations.
The Polícia de Segurança Pública (PSP) has the most prominent urban presence.
The PSP has a diverse range of duties and responsibilities.
The PSP is responsible for protecting the rights of citizens and ensuring democratic legality.
The use of weapons by Portuguese police is permitted only when it is absolutely necessary and when less dangerous means have proved ineffective.
The
Amnesty International published a 2015/2016 annual report on Portugal, in which they criticized the excessive force used by police against migrant and minority communities.
Portugal has a good record in migrant integration.
Historical parallels can be drawn between Portugal's colonial past and modern police racism.
Activists claim that Portuguese police have killed 14 young black men since 2001, with no police officers being held responsible for the deaths.
In February 2015, a young man named Bruno Lopes was aggressively searched and physically abused by police in Cova de Moura, a low socio-economic area with a significant migrant population.
When bystanders protested the excessive force, police responded by firing shotguns loaded with rubber bullets at the witnesses.
On the same day, two human rights workers and five youth entered the Alfragide police station requesting information on Lopes' situation.
The group was allegedly attacked by police officers shouting racist slurs.
The policemen dragged and kept the young men in the police station, where they detained, mistreated, and mocked them for two days.
Seventeen police officers from the Alfragide police station were eventually sent to trial on charges including physical aggression, torture, document forging, and aggravated kidnapping.
As of October 2018, the trial is ongoing, with victims being heard in court.
The European Commission against Racism and Intolerance (ECRI) has expressed concerns about police mistreatment of minorities in Portugal in all of its reports on the country.
In its fifth country report of 2018, ECRI mentioned the Alfragide case in connection to the failure of IGAI to stop the abuses.
IGAI is currently the body responsible for scrutinizing police activities in the country, but it is part of the Ministry of the Interior like the police forces.
In its 2018 report, ECRI recommended that such work should be carried out by the country's Ombudsman, an equality body, or by a new and entirely independent body.

In 2012, Russia's top investigative agency investigated charges of torture by four police officers against detainees.
Human rights activists claim that Russian police use torture techniques to extract false confessions from detainees.
Russian police regulations require officers to meet quotas for solving crimes.
In 2022, during the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Russian police were seen attacking protesters.
In the early days, when Russia was part of the Soviet Union, the secret police and authorities used to detain people and send certain people to the gulags.
Slovakia has systematic police brutality, which is widely documented and almost exclusively enacted on the Romani minority.
The Slovakian government has racist attitudes toward the Romani minority, which dates back to before the split of Czechoslovakia.
The Slovakian government practiced forced sterilization of Romani women and the segregation of the Romani into walled-off settlements.
Excessive use of force against the Romani minority by Slovakian police has been publicly criticized by the United Nations.
The Slovakian police force has been repeatedly condemned by several organizations for lengthy pre-trial detention and its treatment of suspects in custody.
In 2001, a 51-year-old Romani man, Karol Sendrei, died as a result of abuse in police custody at the hands of the Mayor of Magnezitovce and his son who works as a police officer.
The Mayor's son was immediately removed from the police force, and the Mayor was suspended from his position.

The Minister for Internal Affairs attempted to establish new measures to prevent police brutality by including mandatory psychological testing for law enforcement and better training around the effective use of coercion.
In 2009, video footage showed 6 Romani boys aged between 6-16 being forced to strip naked, kiss, and slap each other by Slovakian police officers.
The boys were then set upon by police dogs, with at least two sustaining serious injuries.
Officers attempted to justify their behavior because the boys were suspected of theft against an elderly citizen.
The Romani people in Slovenia lack full rights and legal status.
Police brutality against the Romani in Slovenia is difficult to hold officers accountable for due to their lack of rights and legal status.
Authorities in Slovenia have attempted to rectify discrimination against the Romani by introducing a two-day training program on policing in a multi-ethnic community.

The two-day training program in Slovenia aimed to teach the police about Roma culture and language, build trust between the Roma community and the police, and educate both parties about national and international standards regarding the treatment of minorities.
Tensions between the Romani and the police in Slovenia have been reduced due to the training program but still exist, particularly with police who have not participated in the program.
In November 2012, Slovenian police used excessive force during protests in Maribor, known as the second Maribor uprising.
The violence during the Maribor protests in 2012 included the use of tear gas, physical force, dragging and beating protesters, police dogs, and mounted police charging into the crowd.
The protest in Maribor in 2012 only turned violent after the police started using physical force.
The Francoist dictatorship of Spain repressed protests and strikes in the country using police brutality and state violence during the mass movements of protests in 1968.
In post-Francoist Spain (1975-present), there have been notable demonstrations with police brutality, such as in Barcelona on 27 May 2011 and in Madrid on 25 September 2012.
Video footage from 2011 and 2012 in Spain shows police using force against peaceful demonstrators, including handheld batons, rubber bullets, pepper spray, and causing injuries.

The Spanish government did not reform policing or address police mistreatment of the public after public outrage; instead, new reforms in July 2016 limited the right to freedom of assembly and gave police broad discretion to fine people who show a "lack of respect" towards them.
The Law on Public Security in Spain includes an offence of spreading images
In 2005, Beauty Solomon, an African American immigrant and a prostitute, filed two criminal complaints against Spanish policemen for harassment and physical assault.
Solomon's complaints were based on eyewitness testimony and medical reports confirming her injuries.
The Spanish Courts dismissed Solomon's claims due to insufficient evidence.
Solomon took her case to the European Court of Human Rights, which unanimously ruled in her favor.

The European Court of Human Rights found that Spain had violated Article 3 (prohibition of inhuman and degrading treatment) and Article 14 (prohibition of discrimination) of the European Convention of Human Rights.
The European Court of Human Rights condemned Spain for failing to investigate Solomon's assault and other racist and sexist acts of violence by police officers.
Under Spanish law, the police have the right to check the identity of anyone in a public space when there is a security concern.
African and Latin American immigrants are frequently targeted by police for identity checks, even without a legitimate security concern.
Izza Leghtas, an Amnesty International researcher, stated that people who do not "look Spanish" can be stopped by police as often as four times a day.
In 2013, police shot a man in his own home in front of his wife in the town of Husby, a suburb of Stockholm.
The police alleged that the man had been wielding a machete and threatening them.
The Husby shooting set off more than 100 car torching incidents in Stockholm riots.
When the police showed up during the riots, they had stones thrown at them.
People reported that the police called them "monkeys" and used batons against them in the clash.
In 2013, an African-born Swede was refused entry into a local club in Malmö for wearing traditional African clothes.
The police arrested the man, broke his arm, and locked him in a cell for nearly six hours with no medical aid.
A register of 4029 Romani people is kept by police in Skåne County.
The police claim
Lamin Fatty was detained in Lausanne, October 2017 due to being mistaken for another person with the same name.
Lamin Fatty was found dead in his jail cell the day after he was detained.
Mike Ben Peter died in Lausanne, February 2018 after being held to the ground by police for six minutes.
Mike Ben Peter died of cardiac arrest twelve hours after being held to the ground by police.
There were reports that Mike Ben Peter was repeatedly kicked by the police in his genital area.
An autopsy confirmed severe bruising in Mike Ben Peter's genital region.
The police officers involved with Mike Ben Peter's case were not suspended, but have been charged with negligent homicide in an ongoing case.
Samson Chukwu died in Valais, 2001 due to suffocation as a police officer put their weight on his back while he was face-down.
Authorities originally claimed that Samson Chukwu died of a heart attack.
An autopsy later showed that postural asphyxiation led to Samson Chukwu's death.
Cemal Gomec died in Bern, 2001 after being attacked by police officers with batons to the head, irritant gas, a shock grenade, and rubber bullets.
A sedative is said to have led to cardiac arrest which led to Cemal Gomec's death a few days later.
In the United Kingdom, there were approximately 126,818 police officers employed in the 43 police forces of England, Wales and the British Transport Police in 2015.
This was the lowest number since March 2002.

The 1967 Criminal Law Act, the 2008 Common Law and the Criminal Justice and Immigration Act, the 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act, and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) set out the law and acceptable use of force in the UK.
The use of unnecessary physical force is in principle an infringement of ECHR Article 3.
Cole was left in a vegetative state due to a severed spinal cord after an altercation.
Expert evidence indicated that Cole was struck with considerable force on his neck whilst his head was pulled back.
The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) called for the suspension of the six police officers involved in the altercation with Cole.
Bedfordshire chief constable Colette Paul refused to place the six police officers on restricted duties despite being under criminal investigation.
The Bedfordshire police denied allegations that the use of excessive force on Cole was race-related.
Bedfordshire Police Constables Christopher Thomas and Christopher Pitts chased Faruk Ali before allegedly knocking him over and punching him in the face outside his family home.
Faruk Ali is an autistic man who had the mental age of a five-year-old.
The police officers were accused of laughing throughout the ordeal.
The officers were cleared of misconduct in public office by the Aylesbury Crown Court.
Following an investigation by the IPCC, the officers were fired for breaches of standards of professional conduct.
The breaches of standards of professional conduct included standards of honesty, integrity, authority, equality, and diversity.
Mzee Mohammed died in police custody after being detained by Merseyside police at a Liverpool shopping centre.
Officers were called to the scene after Mzee was allegedly behaving aggressively and erratically while armed with a knife.
Mzee suffered a "medical episode" and was pronounced dead after being detained.
Video evidence surfaced showing Mohammed surrounded by officers and paramedics, seemingly fully unconscious while being placed face down with his hands handcuffed behind his back.
Questions remain about how appropriate medical condition could have been administered given how the handcuffs would restrict breathing.
Mohammed is the 21st black person to die in police custody in six years in North America, Canada.

There have been several high-profile cases of alleged police brutality in Canada, including the 2010 G20 Toronto summit protests, the 2012 Quebec student protests, the Robert Dziekański Taser incident
The Kaiser Family Foundation conducted research and found that almost half of Black Americans believe they have been victimized by law enforcement.
The FBI's 2019 Law Enforcement Officers Killed and Assaulted report, Table 42, states that black persons were responsible for 37% of all officers killed from 2012 through 2019.
A 2021 study published in The Lancet found that more than 30,000 people were killed by police in the United States between 1980 and 2018.
Around 2,500 of those killed by police from 2015 to 2022 were fleeing.
Breonna Taylor was killed at the age of 26 when police forced entry into her apartment as part of an investigation into drug dealing operations.
Taylor was hit by six bullets and died.
In 2020, a state grand jury found the shooting of Taylor justified but indicted officer Brett Hankison on three counts of wanton endangerment for endangering Taylor's neighbors with his shots.
On May 25, 2020, George Floyd, an unarmed African American man, was killed by a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin.
Chauvin knelt on Floyd's neck for over nine minutes (9:29 seconds) while three other officers appeared to restrain his back and legs.
Floyd screamed "You are going to kill me man!" during the incident.
Chauvin was charged with 2nd-degree murder; his three colleagues stand accused of aiding and abetting.
The colleagues of Derek Chauvin include Alexander Kueng, Thomas Lane, and Tou Thao.
Floyd's murder triggered protests against racial discrimination across the US and the world.
In June 2021, former officer Chauvin was found guilty of three counts of murder and manslaughter and received a sentence of 22.5 years in prison.
In Brazil, the police have a history of violence against the lower classes.
The Brazilian police's violent
The COVID-19 pandemic did not stop or diminish the killings. Instead, there was an increase of 27.9% compared to 2019.
Rio's police killed 741 people from January to May 2020, which is the highest rate in 22 years, according to an ISP report.
The ISP research reveals disparities between the number of COVID-19 mitigating actions (36) and police encounters (120) in the first months of the pandemic.
Seventeen organizations from the Black movement, human rights, and favelas organizations joined a political party and entered a petition called ADPF 635 in Brazil's Supreme Court (STF).
The petition, known as "ADPF das Favelas," demands actions towards minimizing police terror in the communities.
In May 2020, the organizations asked for the immediate suspension of police operations during the pandemic.
The request indicated that continuing such operations would threaten life and dignity.
The organizations cited mortality rates, power abuse cases, and the property damages caused by the police raids during a deadly pandemic in poor neighborhoods.
On May 18, 2020, João Pedro Pinto, a 14-year-old boy, was killed inside his family's house.
According to a witness, he lived in a place with a pool and a barbecue area, where he was with his cousins and friends when the police raid started.
The survivors informed that the boys went to the covered area when they noticed that the police helicopter started to shoot.
The police threw two grenades that made the boys run into the house to protect themselves.
João Pedro was shot in his belly by a rifle.
His body was transported to a place 27 miles away from the crime scene, and the family had access to him after 17 hours.
According to the reports and TV news, it was possible to count more than 70 bullet marks inside João Pedro's house.
This murder led people to protest in the streets and was the main argument for the ADPF 635 petition.
The Observatório de Favelas, Maré Vive, Instituto Marielle Franco, Cesec, Grupo de Estudo dos Novos Legalismos/UFF, and Fogo Cruzado contributed to a lawsuit.

In August 2020, the Grupo de Estudos dos Novos Ilegalismos (GENI) from Federal Fluminense University in Rio de Janeiro, along with other civil organizations, stated that after the suspension of police operations by the Supreme Federal Court (STF), the mortality rates decreased to 72.5%.

After the suspension of police operations by the STF, criminality rates also decreased. This reduction included 47.7% in crimes against life, 37.9% in willful murder homicides, 39% in reduction in crimes against patrimonies, and less 32,1% in vehicle robbery.
The STF decision was not well received by Rio de Janeiro's police, who complained that the decision made their work more difficult.
Despite the decrease in criminality, Rio de Janeiro's police did not always obey the order to follow certain requirements during their operations.
According to the Rede de Observatórios, in the first two months of 2021, police killed 47 people, which is 20% more than the same period of 2020.
On May 6, 2021, Rio de Janeiro police killed 28 people in Jacarezinho Favela.

Human rights activists denounced illegal actions after the Jacarezinho Favela raid, including alteration of the crime scene, invasion of houses, and non-compliance with the protocol demanded by the STF.
The Jacarezinho Favela raid is considered the biggest slaughter in the history of the city and is still under investigation.
One month later, on June 08th, a young pregnant Black woman was killed by the police in another favela.
Kathlen Romeu, 24 years old, four months pregnant, was killed by a police officer while walking with her grandmother.
According to the Brazilian Bar Association's Humans Rights Commission (OAB), the operation
Carabineros de Chile is a police force in Chile.
An officer from Carabineros de Chile was shot at by Camilo.
The officer destroyed the SD card from his body camera.
The SD card contained private photos and videos of the officer's wife.
Most people were not satisfied with the explanation provided by Carabineros de Chile for the destruction of the SD card.
The officer was later discharged from his position.
The officer was also prosecuted.
During the 2019-2020 Chilean protests, Carabineros de Chile caused hundreds of eye mutilations.
The eye mutilations were caused by hardened rubber bullets and tear gas canisters.
Gustavo Gatica and Fabiola Campillai are two notable victims who lost complete vision.
During the 2014 Venezuelan protests, multiple human rights organizations condemned the Venezuelan government.
Security forces reportedly used methods beyond typical practices for handling protests.
Methods used included rubber pellets, tear gas, live ammunition, and torture of arrested protestors.
Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch are two organizations that made the condemnation.
Hundreds of Venezuelans were tortured while detained by Venezuelan authorities.
During the 2017 Venezuelan protests, the United Nations Human Rights Office denounced the widespread and systematic use of excessive force against demonstrators.
Security forces and pro-government groups were responsible for the deaths of at least 73 protesters.
The UN Human Rights Office described a pattern of excessive force and arbitrary detentions against demonstrators in Venezuela.
Security forces used disproportionate force to instil fear, crush dissent, and prevent demonstrators from assembling.
The majority of individuals killed during protests died from gunshot wounds.
Many gunshot wounds resulted from the repression by Venezuelan authorities and assisting pro-government colectivos.
Venezuelan security forces raided residential areas and apartment buildings in Caracas and four different states.
